title: Scientific Lenses to Support Multiple Views over Linked Chemistry Data

author: Alasdair J. G. Gray, School of Mathematical and Computer Sciences, Heriot-Watt University

segmentation: This talk is from the Open Facts project, of which I've been involved in the past, and we're going to look at chemistry data if I get too far into the chemistry.
Put your hands up and I'll try and simplify it back.

But we're talking about identity, and there are multiple identifiers for concepts in databases, so there are multiple databases out there about chemicals about biology and they all have identifiers for what might be the same notion.
And this the question in this talk is are they really the same thing?
And how do we allow the users to work with that?
So let's look at a specific example.

This is the compound for Gleevec, which is a leukemia drug, and it's called a matter nip mesylate in the chemical form, and this is the long string across the top is a matter nib and the little cross here is the mess late.
The salt form.
Now, if you were to search for this.
In some chemical databases you get different responses back.
So in chem spider you get the drug.
Imatinib mesylate backs, it's got long string in a little cross.
If you go to drugbank you just get a matter.
If it's just got the long string and if you go to pub chem, you get both imatinib Andermatt and Imes late and the question is which one are these the same thing?
Which one should I use for the query?
And it really depends upon the task that the user is wanting to perform with the data.
So let's look at.
But some tasks that the user might want to do so, for example, the user might be wanting to do a chemical physical chemical analysis which are involves using the weights of chemicals.
In that case, they really want to know that they're getting same substance back.
In another case they might be looking at how the drug interacts with the target in the body.
The proteins in the body, and that case.
It's more.
Search explorative Lee exploratory query.
So looking at this a bit more closely, we got the first task here looking for doing a physical chemical analysis.
In this case we got the Chemspider record on the left and we got drug banking Campbell on the right.
In this case, we want to do a structure match because we're worried about the weights of the chemicals, so we would like.

Mixer chemicals in this way we use the chemical structure and we use a justification which is an inch E string, which is a representation of the chemical structure, and we say these things are exactly the same.
Using this course exact match predicate.
In the other scenario where we're looking for how.

Or the drug interacts with the body where in the search we're in a looser sort of scenario, and so we add in some additional link sets here which say these compounds are the same because they have the same drug name.
So we have a justification of why they are the same.
To enable the switching of these lenses, we have this notion of a scientific lens.
Scientific lens captures the operational equivalence that a user wants to use for their specific task, their search query.
So the lens consists of an identifier so that we know which lens they're referring to.
It's got a short title so that we know roughly what this is, and then there's a description.
The key thing about the description is it has to be understandable to the domain scientist.
Of what are the effects of this lens?

So in this example we got the default lens from the open fax system where we match chemicals based on their chemical structure and so it says chemicals are matched on their structure based on their in cheeky.
And then it says something about targets and pathways 'cause those are other things that we have in the system.
And then in this bottom part here we've got the relationships that we enable when this lens is on.
So let's look at the effects of these lenses.
So one example is the drug ibuprofen.
So I think many of you will be familiar with ibuprofen.

Ibuprofen actually is a stereo enabled chemical, so essentially a chemical is in a flat plane and sometimes you have a bit that sticks up and sometimes a bit that sticks down, and depending on that it can affect how it interacts with the body.
With ibuprofen though, there actually these two stereo forms of it, and they're both equally present in the commercial drug that you buy.
OK, so when you're doing search for ibuprofen, what would you want to get back John to get information back about the stereo independent form that doesn't actually exist in the real world?
Or one of these two forms that exist?
So if you go in with our default lens which matches on chemical structure, what you'll get back is if you go in with the non stereo form of ibuprofens.
If you just type in the name ibuprofen you get back just the non stereo form and any data that's connected with that form.
If you go in with one of the stereoisomers you just get that stereoisomer back.
This doesn't actually answer the users query of how does ibuprofen interact with the body, what they are.
We want to see is all of the information back, regardless of what they've used as the entry point.
So for this we enable what we call the stereo chemistry lens.
So where does all our data come from for this so we get the data?
From the data sources and we first validate that the data in the chemical sources is accurate.
There is a huge amount of messy data out there, so we first of all make sure that what we're getting in is valid.
Once we got the valid data, we Jenna.
Right certain properties about it, its molecular weight.
It's inches string.
Other properties of whether it's a stereochemistry enabled compound or not.
From that information we then get computationally generate link sets with different justifications of why 2.
Chemicals are related, so in the first case here, it's because it's the non stereo parents of it.
In the second case it's because it is a stereo sibling of it and we actually have about 17 of these relationship types for chemicals alone.
This has been realized in the real system so.
So this is a screenshot from the Explorer of the Open fax system, and these lenses are now enabled in our test version.
So in this first case you got the ibuprofen and all we get back because we've gone in with a standard lens is the information about ibuprofen and we got about 2300 pharmacology results there.
Now we turn on.
The stereochemistry lens and the number of.
Pharmacology results has increased from 2300 to over 3000, and you see that we get three different chemical structures down at the bottom.
So this is part of the bigger open fax project.
We ingest data from public data sources.
It goes through our architecture and all of this lens enabled work is done separately from the Triple Store.
So we have the data in a triple store and then the lenses and the mappings that support them in a separate identity management service.
How do we?
So just checking what my next slide is.
Yes, so how do we make use of that information?
So when a user comes in with a query, this gets translated into a sparkle query so they come in with the keyword search.
We translate it to a sparkle query over our system which has separate graph clauses.
We extract the idente.
Fires from that sparkle query.
We pass it to our mapping service to get lens that they are wanting to use for their operational equivalents.
We
Get back the chemicals that are notionally equivalent to that and then we use those identifiers to.
Expand And populate the query so we say.

In this case there's a filter clause, so we've replaced the original compound identifier with a variable and then we put in a filter clause saying these things are all equivalent, and there's obviously some multiple optimizations you can do because in this case we know we're in the chem spider graph, so we only use.
The Chemspider identifier.
But then there's another graph clause underneath where we'd maybe use a different one of the identifiers.
The open fax.
Form is in use so since it launched in April 2013, we've had almost 30 million hits to the API.
So this stuff is being used.
So to conclude.
Well, I'm through to the end.
I'll give you the life demo then if I got time.
OK, so I can actually show you this live then so.
Typing in ibuprofen.
We first see that it's doing some disambiguation step and then we eventually find ibuprofen and we click search.
This goes away 'cause the system and as the query expansion steps that I was showing you OK and the top compound here is ibuprofen.
So we see this is exactly what I showed you in the screenshot.
You get the chemical substance back.
Some key properties of it, and we get the pharmacology results.
So this is how many results are known about how this compound interacts with the body and we've got about 2370 there at the bottom.
We've got no pictures.
We select a lens so this is gone in with our default lens which just matches on chemical compounds.
And here we're going to choose the stereo chemistry lens which turns on the stereoisomer links.
We click apply.
And what we see here is the pharmacology count has gone up to 3000 or over 3000 and we've got the different chemicals coming back at the bottom.
If I still click on the pharmacology link, you'll actually go and get those results under that lens.
So it's all follows through.
So I will conclude this time, so scientific data is complex.
It's not very well understood how it all interacts with each other.

The data that we have in the available data sources is messy, it's incomplete, so this requires that we enable flexible linking of the datasets underneath so that the users can control when they want to see information, or when they don't.
Equivalence depends on the type of task that the user is doing, so they need, so they may even for the same task want different notions of equivalence.

So I've shown you ibuprofen if I'd chosen from aldehyde, you wouldn't want to see both stereo forms there, because one is responsible for birth defects and the other one is good for sort of eliminating nausea, and we've been able to generate the links that enable these lenses based on chemical computations.
And generating justification saying why two things are equivalent?
This is an.
Just my work.
It's part of a much larger consortium.
These are my coauthors on this paper.
There's about 21 there, so thank you to all my coauthors.
They're the people who've been involved with implementing this system, discussing the pharmacology behind it, the use cases, and they've all fed into this paper.
So I'll leave you with my contact details tonight.
I'll be in the demo session providing a demonstration of one of the tools we've developed in open fax, but I'll also be happy to demonstrate the lenses to you at the same time, so thank you.
So the question is, we use different predicates for the matches, so we've got some which are exact match some that are close match.

These are driven by the chemist, so the chemists have developed the process by which we determine when two chemicals are the same and they've decided whether a relationship team is deemed to be a close match or an exact match.
So we've discussed with them what these things mean.

But rather more important than which actual predicate is there is the justification, and it's the justifications that power the lenses here so we don't actually pay very close attention to the link predicate, but rather sort of use the justification to say this is going to be turned on for this particular query, or off, as the case may be.
Thanks Alastair, yeah that's very nice work.
Can you comment a little bit about the applicability of the method with respect to the other kinds of pharmaco pharmacological data that's of interest in open packs and in the open fax platform?
So going beyond just chemical data going into the biology data that we sort of mentioned, you know the the protein targets, for instance, and so do you have any plans to extend this.
So the chemicals because of their structure has been very amenable to this automatic computational approach to generating links.
With biology there isn't such a good way of computing the links automatically.
However, there are multiple links in datasets.

As you know, various databases say I'm a close match or I have a database cross reference to this other data set, and so we're looking at how we can maybe extract those and get talk with the publishers to find out what the justifications behind those are.
But it's finding out why there are those database cross reference links is the real challenge there.
Hi there, thanks for a very interesting talk.
I just had a quick question.
The first step in your process was invalidation.
Right checking whether the results are valid.
So how do you do that exactly?
Checking that?
So it's very much on the chemical structure.
So very often you'll find that the chemicals, so there's a set of FDA rules in that state.
How are chemical should be represented for drugs?
And so the these are being.

Worked out how to represent them computationally and then we take the chemical structure that's given in and we check whether it's got the right charge balance on it, whether it's got the right number of hydrogen bonds represented as and then some of these, we can correct automatically.
Others of them get flagged up to our curators to say what's going on here.
We've got this sort of warning and then they can either manually correct it or go back and contact the data supplier.
OK, thank you.
Thank you Mr.
Going back actually falling off the second question.

I know one way identifying entity how to actually retrieve the whole integrated picture as available in limited API API.

The infrastructure is completely independent of chemistry, so the only bit that relies on chemical knowledge is designing how to generate the links and then sort of saying which links are enabled in a lens.

And looking at the questions, they want to answer and seeing whether these lenses do enable one of the challenges is in explaining to them what are the effects of the lens and why would you want to use one lens over another.
So I said we had 17 relationships.
If we show them 17 different lenses, they just get overwhelmed and they can't decide which one to use.
But then when you start sort of amalgamating lenses together, it becomes quite complicated to explain to them what to expect from one lens or another.
So it's trying to get the right tradeoff, so we're actively working with our internal users to find out how to do that.
